reviewText:
In this game, which, by the way, quickly became one of my favorite in Heroes francise, player takes control of common M&M races and fights in huge fantasy world, crafted with colorful and beautiful graphics.
What certainly makes to enjoy this game are battles. It`s not exactly a turn based strategy like Heroes series, more like a tactical puzzle game with simple RPG elements and without typical town management from others Heroes games. Battles itself are original and have a lot of depth, but at the same time they are quick and very easy to pick up and play. Nevertheless, later levels and multiplayer matches require a lot of planning and knowledge about various units and races. One problem, though, is the lack of information about tactics and unit's abilities in mid game.
Plot follows a group of young heroes, who tries to save the world of Ashan from the mystical enemy, as it killed their parents, rulers of Ashan. Story is fairly interesting, but personally I didn't liked it as much as similar, episodic story from Heroes VI.
Music is always terrific in Heroes games, but I liked this one the most, soundtrack equally shines in both: battles and story cutscenes.
Online mode doesn't require to level up, as special units and artifacts can only be unlocked in campaign. The result is balanced and skill dependent battles, without long, off-putting grind.

Overall, M&M: Clash of Heroes doesn't lose originality or depth despite it's simplicity and for such a tiny price I can't remember another game, which offers so many hours of gameplay... Bloody fun gameplay.

reviewText:
This is a nifty little title that blends together Match-3 dynamics with a tactical combat layer.  You form columns of like-colored creatures to form an attack or rows of like-colored creatures to create a wall.  Different creatures have different characteristics (e.g., Elven Archers attack very quickly but do modest damage, while Human Swordsmen attack much more slowly but hit harder).   Heroes level up to gain HP and stronger walls, and each hero has one unique ability (plus a second unique ability that can come from any particular magic item you find along the way).

It's not one of the deepest Match games I've ever played (nowhere near as deep as Ironcast, say), but it's a fun little game.  It's also GREAT to share with small kids whom you want to play games with.  I played it with my 5-year old son and we completed the whole campaign together!  The story is cute and entertaining, but unlikely to win a Nobel Prize for Literature.

The tie to Might and Magic is very loose, but it's still a fun little title.

reviewText:
Ever since this game was introduced to me by my friend Liam, i've been addicted to it.

It's such a good puzzle game and really rewards clever thinking and forward planning. Think chess meets tetris sort of,
It has an awesome multiplayer and...oh my god the music. How can anyone dislike the music?! It's so dramatic and entrancing, i ended up getting the soundtrack just so i could hear it on demand. Totally badass stuff.

Different teams have different abilities and special units, but i much prefer the undead team of vampires, ghosts, zombies etc

The game looks beautiful too; there really isn't anything bad i could say about it. I suppose they could have made a few more music tracks for battles, but i say that only because i love the handful they have already!

I feel that this game is deceptively underrated.

If you ever wanted a puzzle-strategy-RPG-type game (think: like Puzzle Quest), this is the one to go for. The mechanics are very well-designed, the in-game assets and UI look great at any resolution, and the single-player content will likely be satisfying until completion. Being able to kick-back with a 360 controller is also a plus.

Despite being a genre hybrid and having RNG, strategy and tactics actually plays a significant role, as you can customize your unit/hero/item loadout before every game, and can try-out different things once on the field. For example, you could use units/heroes that are quick to charge-up, and have them all constantly bombard your opponent from multiple points, making it difficult to defend against. Or you could focus on using strong hero units (which a player has a limited number of) that take a while to charge, but have a lot of damage-output once its turn comes and if it hasn't taken too much damage from your opponent before then. Or just about any loadout combination and tactics you can think-up.

The game also uses high-resolution art assets and an automatically-scaling UI, so the game will look great at any resolution. And the unit animations themselves (especially the Hero attack animations) are both well-done and expressive, but won't make the field difficult to grok at any point. I run the game at 1440p without any issues.

As far as the single-player mode, I thought it was well-done. While the story and characters are kind-of garbage, and I didn't like starting a new character for each chapter, the game's difficulty sloped-up very satisfyingly, and every boss was a novelty that forced you to change your tactics. I believe the reason for this is because of each character's level-cap, where the later bosses/mini-bosses in each area were all crafted for you to be at that cap, so that you couldn't just grind your way out for an easy victory against them. Aside from the bit-too-easy battles at the start and the huge difficulty ramp at the final boss, the single-player was satisfying and challenging enough to pull me the entire way through.

If you've been looking for a puzzle-RPG hybrid and want a chill game to kick back with, I'd recommend M&M: CoH. Just bring a controller.

A casualized (but in a good way) take on the HOM&M franchise, mized with tile matching puzzle elements.\nCertainly won't wow you with incredible complexity, depth of mechanics, massive world to explore or an epic plot - but what is there is executed competently.\nClash Of Heroes is quite fun and enjoyable to play, even if the gameplay overall may feel a bit simplistic compared to the rest of HOM&M franchise.

For all the Match-3 games with RPG elements, there is no title that satisfies quite like Clash of Heroes. reviewText:
Clash of Heroes is a very convincing argument for spin-offs to popular franchises - who would have thought that the dowdy dungeon crawlers of yore would provide an excellent foundation for a more tactical alternative to Puzzle Quest?

The lengthy single player campaign (we are talking 20-30 hours with a few unnecessary tedious / difficult battles happening every now and then) takes place in a Heroes of Might & Magic V inspired setting, including cameos, and introduces five likeable heroes in their intertwined quests to stop a power-hungry wizard hellbent on destroying Ashan and plunging it into chaos. All presented with handdrawn cutscenes and suitable epic music.

Battles will draw you in with the beautiful, easy to understand mechanics that do offer more tactical freedom than similar puzzle games as you can actually plan ahead for a few turns. Combined with some light rpg elements (leveling up units and equipping your hero with artifacts) it is certainly possible to develop a personal playstyle and come up with your own nasty strategies to obliterate your foes.
Be warned, the luck-factor can be high at times - as units are spawned randomly and timing is everything in this game.

The visuals are beautifully executed, especially the animations deserve praise - all rendered in sharp hd-resolution - combined with the excellent soundtrack you get a very well presented package.

On top of it all there is an excellent (maybe a bit barebones)  multiplayer-mode that will make sure you keep this beauty on your harddrive for a few quick matches with friends every now and then. Overall a very enjoyable title that has tons of contents and very addictive core-mechanics that will keep you entertained for a long time.

I love the art design of this game, which is one the main reason I gave the game a spin(the other being curious about HoMM universe). It's part puzzle and part strategy, and whole lot of luck. You set up an army before battle selecting 3 core units (read: cannon fodder/fuel), and two specail units(either elite or ultimate). Core units can attack by making a vertical line of three same color unit(plus charge time). Walls are made by a horizontal line of three same colored core units(these absorb damage of course). The special units need to be powered by the corresponding colored core unit placed behind the special unit(elite 2 units and ultimate 4 units). You also get a special move that differs on the hero leading your army. In single player they're all are balanced, but in mutiplayer you gain access to some broken characters due to their magic skill. Items can be equip to give you an advantage. Story is standard fare, fun gameplay, and some very funny one-off characters. I liked it.

A pretty simplistic game in appearance that reveals its complexity through a single hour of playtime.

The basic 3-units principle(to make an attack, three vertical units of the same colour, to make walls, three horizontal) gets immensely complex and varied once you add links(having groups of the same colour attack at the same turn) that reinforce your attack, fusions(two attack groups one behind the other fuse into one group twice as strong), and of course Elite and Champion units that require 2 and 4 units to activate them.

Almost every single unit from every single race has a specific capacity, poison, jumping over walls, magical defenses, immunity to attack while charging, hacking the enemy lines/enemy charging power while charging, the variety added to the basic 3-units system makes this an incredibly capable game with possibilities that never seem to be insufficient no matter the circumstances. You can literally be about to be killed by your enemy, call reinforcements, and find yourself gifted with a generous unit placement that allows you to build the walls and defenses you need to just survive and counterattack to victory. There is a freshness in this game that never dies out.

It's actually one of its greatest strengths and weaknesses, how random the battles can go. You can be gifted with a perfect line of units from the very start or have absolutely nothing to go on with. The game can be very frustrating when a perfectly planned attack is ruined by the sudden arrival of an enemy Champion just in the column you're about to use to finish off your foe. It can also be frustrating in the other way: you will call reinforcements to see one of your costly Champion units die immediately at the hands of some basic enemy attack with 2 attack because you couldn't get it moving in time.

As frustrating and unfair as the randomness is, it is also one of this game's best aspects. The only reason I speedrun this game is that it has the merit of never(apart from the tutorials) making me feel like déjà vu. Every battle is at least new enough, no moments in the game feel like I've been here before(except the bosses, of which there are only 4, along with quite a few unfair pre-prepared battles) and even when it does happen, the randomness of the reinforcements usually palliates that very quickly.

Gameplay-wise, it's simply excellent. Having played through the campaign quite a few times for speedrunning, I have yet to find this game to bore me at any point, and it's quite surprising to realise how a simple system can be at the same time constantly demanding and very free.
A good example is the fusions: if you want one, with core, Elite or Champion units, you're gonna have to get rid of all your walls first, since you need six tiles to make any fusion and there are only six between the goal your enemy has to hit and your first line.

Beyond that, every hero has got his own superpower which can range from somewhat poor(hello Cyrus) to ridiculously broken when you know how to use them(hello Aidan with lots of walls, Anwen with a clear opening, Markal with two uncharged Death Knights).

Beyond beyond that, artifacts can be found in many flavors in the campaign and then used profusely in skirmishes or online battles. And the variety there is by no means inferior to the one in the units, although I'm sure everyone will end up using ridiculously strong artifacts like the Spider Cloak, Lion's Mane or Celerity Ring.

On a side note, the balancing of the campaigns is a bit poor. Why is Nadia not only ridiculously rich in HP(she starts at level 7 out of 10!), but also given enemies that play defensively, troops that make almost no damage, and is also generously dotted with Academy enemies, who can raise layers of superwalls like drinking a cup of coffee? It makes her campaign ridiculously long and just unpleasant. The times I get for Anwen range under 50 minutes, Godric takes less than an hour, Fiona has a rather long campaign that takes about 1h10 minutes, Aidan has a rather short campaign that also takes less than an hour, and Nadia ends up taking me 1 hour 40 minutes!

Continuing on the bad side, the story is completely ignorable. It's not bad(no big plot holes, awful writing or terrible characters) but absolutely nothing about it feels in any way original. The characters almost feel stereotypical, you have the courageous and honorable big brother, the courageous but more sheltered little sister, the more angsty teenage younger brother, the huntress of the woods, the good student girl who fights the good fight...

All of their personalities can be written in a quick line and although they never made me facepalm(none of the main five anyway), the last thing I wanted was to be tasked with finding an interesting personality trait among them. I don't mind finding needles in haystacks, but this is just impossible.

The story is of the same type, it's nothing awful, but it doesn't convey anything even remotely amusing or deep. It ends in a happy note that works but doesn't really follow the somewhat tragic storytelling we had for most of the game. It's not really light on clichés and nothing about it is worth mentioning. I had a laugh once in the entire game. A giggle, really, at the demon who dies from the volcanic eruption he wanted to see. The rest is skippable. Special mention, though, to the villains: they range from comic relief(Azexes and his forgetful schoolboy behavior) to so obvious it hurts(Carlyle and his fashion for being a general ♥♥♥♥).

Visually, I like the animé art style quite a lot, and the quality of the animations is certainly very helpful at making it a nice game to watch. I do have a serious issue about those: they're long. REALLY long. Sometimes it's ok, but seeing the knight twirl his spear around before charging for the 1000th time has really grown old. Less long animations would've really helped in making the game a lot more fun. The PLAYER TURN and ENEMY TURN screens are also ridiculous, they last something like 3,5 seconds! Talk about a needless loss of time! Those could've simply not existed and all would've been better.

As much as I appreciate the animé visual style for almost everyone, some races are totally failed: the good guys and necromancers are mostly fine, but the magicians' golems or titans look nothing like the machines they are, although that's nothing in comparison to the Demons and how every unit but the hound is failed. Even when lit with flames and about to strike, I find it difficult to take the immense Pit Fiend more seriously than a plushie. Demons look neither scary nor ugly, and that's a true minus for me.

With all that said, the last element is the music.
It sucks.
No other way to say it. This game has very poor music.
Out of five campaigns, forests, a capital city of men, the land of the undead, Hell, and a mighty Magician tower, I remember exactly zero theme songs. Why? Because there aren't any songs. It's all ambients. BAD ambients, with no memorable sounds at all. Whooshing winds and shaking leaves, that's all.
The battle musics are thankfully very varied, however that would be a good thing only if they didn't all suck as well! Out of the eight or so battle themes, there is one I like. The final boss music is fine too. The victory theme(the first 4 seconds of it anyway) and the two former are the only songs I can say I appreciate musically out of the whole game. Having played HoMM5 before, I know that many of these songs were taken from the rest of the franchise and sort of put in this one. It doesn't fit, none of the songs are that good, so it's a game that is terribly uninteresting musically.

A lot more could be said about bad minigames, Sonic 06-type loading times(two loading times into each battle), but I reached the limit.
Final word is that despite my complaints, this is an incredibly fun and varied game that always develops into more complexity and fun. Try it.

Less long animations would've really helped in making the game a lot more fun. The PLAYER TURN and ENEMY TURN screens are also ridiculous, they last something like 3,5 seconds! Talk about a needless loss of time! Those could've simply not existed and all would've been better.

As much as I appreciate the animé visual style for almost everyone, some races are totally failed: the good guys and necromancers are mostly fine, but the magicians' golems or titans look nothing like the machines they are, although that's nothing in comparison to the Demons and how every unit but the hound is failed. Even when lit with flames and about to strike, I find it difficult to take the immense Pit Fiend more seriously than a plushie. Demons look neither scary nor ugly, and that's a true minus for me.

With all that said, the last element is the music.
It sucks.
No other way to say it. This game has very poor music.
Out of five campaigns, forests, a capital city of men, the land of the undead, Hell, and a mighty Magician tower, I remember exactly zero theme songs. Why? Because there aren't any songs. It's all ambients. BAD ambients, with no memorable sounds at all. Whooshing winds and shaking leaves, that's all.
The battle musics are thankfully very varied, however that would be a good thing only if they didn't all suck as well! Out of the eight or so battle themes, there is one I like. The final boss music is fine too. The victory theme(the first 4 seconds of it anyway) and the two former are the only songs I can say I appreciate musically out of the whole game. Having played HoMM5 before, I know that many of these songs were taken from the rest of the franchise and sort of put in this one. It doesn't fit, none of the songs are that good, so it's a game that is terribly uninteresting musically.

A lot more could be said about bad minigames, Sonic 06-type loading times(two loading times into each battle), but I reached the limit.
Final word is that despite my complaints, this is an incredibly fun and varied game that always develops into more complexity and fun. Try it.

The game is a really fun puzzle/strategy game with solid gameplay mechanics and nice art. Unfortuneatly it is plagued by bugs and doesn't seem to be getting any real support from the developers so far.

Multiplayer is particularly bad. There is no penalty for people quitting games or constantly lagging out. There is no real lobby to browse all the open games, their rules, and the players hosting them. There is no way to see how many people are on and willing to play multiplayer, so you have no idea if you are likely to get a game soon or the only one online. Once you start looking for a multiplayer game, you can't do anything else. It would make a lot more sense to be able to go play single player until your multiplayer match was ready, but no one thoght of that and the game is basically abandoned at this point so unlikely to get any such updates (plus it was basically a console port as it was).

All of this works against building a thriving multiplayer community, driving people away, which creates a viscious cycle. The people that are left playing are the most hardcore of the hardcore, resulting in uneven match-ups of a level 7 player against a level 378 player, because there isn't enough of a player pool to do any fair matchmaking.

It's a real shame that it suffers from these basic UI and matchmaking design flaws, because the actual gameplay is fantastic. Despite all of these issues, I'd recommend the game, just make sure some of your friends get a copy because that's pretty much the only way you'll get to have any fun in multiplayer.

„Might and Magic: Clash of Heroes” is a spin off of popular series „Heroes: Might and Magic”. Just like „Might and Magic Dark Messiah” this game doesn't have much in common with original series. It is more like „Puzzle Quest” rather than „Heroes”.
Gameplay is based on puting units in formations, which, depending on the arrangement will attack opponent or put defensive walls . When you put 3 units of the same colour in column, these units will join in formation and attack after charging time. And if you put three units of the same color in a row they will turn into the wall that will block the opponent's attacks .
Just like in „Heroes: Might and Magic” we have various factions. We will lead units of elves, humans, undead, demons and mages. Each of these factions has its own units and various mechanics associated with them. In addition to the basic units we have all kinds of special and elite units. Special units activate by putting two standard units of the same colour behind them. Elite units activate by putting two rows of two basic units of the same color. Every faction have its own special creatures, for example ents, dragons or angels. Each one of them have their own special ability. For example druid's attack extends load time of opponent's unit, which gives you time to counter their attack. Not only the units have special skills, also your characters have their own powers.
Storyline is not deep enough to impress me. The scenario looks like it was written for some children cartoon. Demons attacked unsuspecting kingdoms with intention of conquest. If you were expecting interesting plot in this title, you couldn't be more wrong.

Verdict: This one was a surprise. A beautiful, polished game with excellent presentation, surprising strategic depth and a simple but engaging story. The best Heroes of Might and Magic game for quite some time. 8/10

Story: The story is simple and light but, married with the clean presentation, is still an endearing and somewhat engaging experience. Straightforward but nevertheless interesting characters will appeal to most people, and the big names to Heroes fans in particular. 6/10

Gameplay:  I should start this by saying that I hate Match 3 games with a burning passion. But it feels wrong to even call this Match 3; it feels more like genuine turn-based strategy. Each side takes turns moving units around to match three and create ‘formations’, which then attack the other side. This is simple at first but, as you unlock new units and combinations, it becomes much more complex and interesting. It’s a very well-balanced game with offensive, defensive and mixed strategies all being equally viable. 9/10

Graphics: The presentation is excellent, colourful and polished, and the attack animations are powerful. It’s surprisingly fun to see classic Heroes characters rendered in an anime style. 8/10

Sound/Music: The sound is great and the re-mastered soundtrack will cause Heroes fans to reminisce like crazy.  8/10

I've given this game enough chances to prove itself.

There is no option to customize opponents in quick battle mode.

The UI is confusing and too little data is given about conditions of the units and the walls.

The game lacks a 'one move undo' button which would eliminate harmfulness of accidental button presses (issue mostly with laptops).

The game lacks a quick way to restart the battle, making campaigns tedious due to long process of loading a save and initializing the battle again.

The game keeps f***ing freezing when you win a battle (see screenshots). However, the condition seems to be that the Sylvan dragon attacks on the last turn.

The whole game is basically based on RNG, making victories hollow and losses frustrating without chance to learn.

This is a very cool mix of puzzle(match 3 type, kinda sorta) and mild rpg elements.  You are combating opponents similar to puzzle quest style, but with more focus on position of units and matches.  Additionally the match 3 part is way more strategy based, you are not just swapping two adjacent blocks.  Combine that with hero powers and unit(aka block types) that level up, and you've got a really good filler strategy game that will provide a brain challenge but won't melt your brain.  highly recommned this, especially when it goes on sale!
